lines.text: Upon Memory Consolidation."
Kalter B. Essnan, M.D., Ph.D.
PROGRESS REPORT
Principal Investigator
Queens College of the City University
January 16, 1973 to
of New York
August 1, 1974.
65-30 Kissena Blvd.
Flushing, New York
STUDIES OF NICOTINE ACTION UPON MEMORY CONSOLDIATION
Within the past 17 months, or since the submission of a previous progress
report for this research project (January 16, 1973 - Aug. 1, 1974), the research
has been specifically concerned with the interaction of putative neurotrans-
mitters and the central effects of nicotine and several of its biologically active
metabolites. Changes in brain serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) metabolism have,
in previous research, been established in conjunction with several amesic agents
and/or events, several of which appear to be temporally contiguous with the amesic
associated inhibition of cerebral protein synthesis. Such effects, particularly as
brought about experimentally through the administration of electroconvulsive shock
(ECS) have been antagonized or blocked through the administration, prior to
administration of the amesia stimulus of nicotine. These effects have been docu-
mented in previous publications fromsour laboratory. Ke have also demonstrated
that Several metabolites of nicotine, naxely cotinine and 3-pyridylacetic acid, are
capable of antagonizing the amnesic effects brought about by post-training ECs and
simi larly alter the effects of such ECS upon brain 5-HT metabolites. These effects
have also been shown to be time-dependent to the extent that 45 minutes appears to
be optimal following nicotine injection, after which the amesic properties of ECS
are antagonized, whereas 15 minutes after treatment, the effects appear to be
potentiated. In Figure 1, these behavioral data have been summarized for nicotine
and several of its derivatives.
